\chapter{List Management (L.I.M.A)}
\label{\detokenize{index:list-management-l-i-m-a}}
A python based software that ingests 3rd-party tabular (excel, csv, etc.) files for conference and rep lists and aims to ensure that a Salesforce CRM is up-to-date.

At it’s core, LIMA is a matching system that can push necessary updates, given a data input. Enabling LIMA are a number of great libraries:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/pandas/}{pandas}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/salesforce-bulk/}{salesforce-bulk}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/selenium/}{selenium}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/scikit-learn/}{scikit-learn}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/simple-salesforce/}{simple-salesforce}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/us/}{us}

\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/uszipcode/}{uszipcode}

\end{itemize}


\section{How lists are processed}
\label{\detokenize{index:how-lists-are-processed}}\sphinxhref{static/list\_process.png}{\sphinxincludegraphics{{static/list_process}.png}}

\section{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{index:usage}}

\subsection{Full process}
\label{\detokenize{index:full-process}}
To leverage the entire functionality of the list program (LIMA), you need only perform the below.
New in version 4.0 is the ability to specify if you’re manually running (ad-hoc) or if it’s being controlled by a bot (cron’d/scheduled).

\fvset{hllines={, ,}}%
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{ListManagement.list\PYGZus{}processing} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{ListProcessing}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} to run in manual/ad\PYGZhy{}hoc mode}
\PYG{n}{lp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ListProcessing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{manual}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{main\PYGZus{}contact\PYGZus{}based\PYGZus{}processing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} to run in cron\PYGZsq{}d/auto mode}
\PYG{n}{lp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{ListProcessing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{auto}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{main\PYGZus{}contact\PYGZus{}based\PYGZus{}processing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Individual components}
\label{\detokenize{index:individual-components}}
The modules within the search node of LIMA lend themselves well to ad-hoc/one-off searches. Using the tools like the below will parse your input file into one (or more) output files.


\subsubsection{Finra}
\label{\detokenize{index:finra}}
If you have a list of advisors where your data contains either a CRD number, or has the advisor’s First, Last, and Company name, you can leverage the power of the Finra API. See the documentation for more details.

\fvset{hllines={, ,}}%
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{ListManagement.search.finra} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Finra}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{PythonUtilities.LoggingUtility} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Logging}

\PYG{n}{log} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Logging}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Lima\PYGZhy{}Finra\PYGZhy{}AdHoc}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{LM\PYGZus{}FAH}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{logger}
\PYG{n}{fin} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Finra}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{path} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZti{}/your/path/to/a/file.xlsx}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{n}{fin}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{scrape}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{parse\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{True}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{save}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{True}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Salesforce}
\label{\detokenize{index:salesforce}}
Similar to the Finra scenario, if you have a file with CRD, Email, or or has the advisor’s First, Last, and Company name, you can leverage the power of the Salesforce Search API. See the documentation for more details.

\fvset{hllines={, ,}}%
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{ListManagement.search.salesforce} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Search}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{PythonUtilities.LoggingUtility} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Logging}

\PYG{n}{log} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Logging}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Lima\PYGZhy{}Searc\PYGZhy{}AdHoc}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{LM\PYGZus{}SAH}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{logger}
\PYG{n}{search} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Search}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{path} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZti{}/your/path/to/a/file.xlsx}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{n}{search}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{perform\PYGZus{}search\PYGZus{}one}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{searching\PYGZus{}list\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{list\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Campaign}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Search chaining}
\label{\detokenize{index:search-chaining}}
Similar to how the LIMA uses these modules, you can manufacture (if necessary) a similar process to take a given file, search it against 1) Salesforce, 2) attempt to identify any not found via a BrokerCheck search (Finra) and 3) research against Salesforce.

\fvset{hllines={, ,}}%
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{ListManagement.search} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{salesforce}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{finra}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{PythonUtilities.LoggingUtility} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Logging}

\PYG{n}{log} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Logging}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Lima\PYGZhy{}Finra\PYGZhy{}AdHoc}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{LM\PYGZus{}CAH}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{logger}
\PYG{n}{sf\PYGZus{}search} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{salesforce}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Search}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{fin\PYGZus{}search} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{finra}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Finra}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{extracted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{File Path}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZti{}/your/path/to/a/file.xlsx}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{extracted}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sf\PYGZus{}search}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{perform\PYGZus{}search\PYGZus{}one}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{searching\PYGZus{}list\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{extracted}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{File Path}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{list\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Campaign}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{extracted}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fin\PYGZus{}search}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{scrape}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{extracted}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{File Path}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{scrape\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{crd}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{parse\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{True}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{extracted}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sf\PYGZus{}search}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{perform\PYGZus{}search\PYGZus{}two}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{extracted}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{FINRA\PYGZus{}SEC Found}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{extracted}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Found Path}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{list\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Campaign}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Written by Ricky Schools, with help from Max Charles, for FS Investments.


\chapter{ListManagement package}
\label{\detokenize{index:module-ListManagement}}\label{\detokenize{index:listmanagement-package}}\index{ListManagement (module)}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:module-ListManagement.list_processing}}\index{ListManagement.list\_processing (module)}

\section{list\_processing.py}
\label{\detokenize{index:list-processing-py}}
The core module that orchestrates matching
for 3rd party documents (excel, csv, et al) and
updates the Salesforce CRM for FS Investments.

Handles Broker Dealer (Account) and Business Development
Group (BizDev Group) updated representative
lists (typically received monthly and quarterly, respectively).

Handles attendee lists for events and conferences (Campaigns)
where FS Investments has committed money.
\index{ListProcessing (class in ListManagement.list\_processing)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:ListManagement.list_processing.ListProcessing}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ListManagement.list\_processing.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{ListProcessing}}}{\emph{mode='manual'}}{}
Bases: \sphinxhref{https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html\#object}{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}}

Orchestrates all matching and updates for pending list requests.
\index{account\_processing() (ListManagement.list\_processing.ListProcessing method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:ListManagement.list_processing.ListProcessing.account_processing}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{account\_processing}}}{\emph{\_vars}}{}
Handles all processing for lists that are sourced from the account object.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi )}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi )}\makeatother
\item {} 
Predicts headers and pre\_process each file.

\item {} 
Searches against SalesForce for matches on: a) CRDNumber b) AMPFId c) Email d) LookupName.

\item {} 
If advisors are not found, scrape data from FINRA based on First, Last, and Account Name.

\item {} 
If advisors are scraped, re-search those advisors against SalesForce.

\item {} 
For all found advisors, scrape their licenses (and other metadata) from FINRA

\item {} 
Parse list into actionable pieces: a) upload to campaign b) create c) not found.

\item {} 
Update the ‘Last List Upload’ field on the account record.

\item {} 
Prepare data for upload into SalesForce (via source\_channel function), do so for each file created above.

\item {} 
Extract stats from search processing, send notification email, and update SalesForce list record.

\item {} 
If applicable, drop files in the bulk\_processing network drive to create or update SaleForce contacts.

\end{enumerate}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{\_vars}} \textendash{} Python dictionary containing metadata regarding a list request.

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode


\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
Nothing

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{main\_contact\_based\_processing() (ListManagement.list\_processing.ListProcessing method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:ListManagement.list_processing.ListProcessing.main_contact_based_processing}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{main\_contact\_based\_processing}}}{}{}
This method determines how to route a pending list request, based on the Salesforce object type.
\begin{description}
\item[{An abstracted path looks like the following:}] \leavevmode\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi )}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi )}\makeatother
\item {} 
Check if there are pending lists.  \# TODO: Add check before looping through each list.

\item {} 
If lists are pending, begin looping through all available lists.

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{Check that each pending list is of a workable extension.}] \leavevmode\begin{description}
\item[{See Also: ListProcessing().is\_bad\_extension() method for extensions that}] \leavevmode
will stop the processing.

\end{description}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{If the list has an acceptable extension, enter a}] \leavevmode
routing statement to determine which rules to process the list request
through.

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{After completing processing, notify the requester, record stats, and}] \leavevmode
begin processing any additional lists.

\end{description}

\end{enumerate}

\end{description}

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
Nothing

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{scrape() (ListManagement.search.finra.Finra method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:ListManagement.search.finra.Finra.scrape}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{scrape}}}{\emph{path}, \emph{alter\_name=None}, \emph{scrape\_type=None}, \emph{parse\_list=False}, \emph{save=False}}{}
User level method allowing them access to the Finra ‘API’. Given a tabular file (Excel, CSV),
a user can specify:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi )}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi )}\makeatother
\item {} 
The scrape type (‘all’, see self.\_x\_paths above, or ‘crdnumber’) they desire to perform.

\item {} 
If they want to save the results of the file.

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{An option to parse the results of the scrape into 3 parts: (typically for scrape\_type=’crdnumber’}] \leavevmode\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumii{\alph{enumii}}
\def\labelenumii{\theenumii )}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumiii{\p@enumii \theenumii )}\makeatother
\item {} 
Found

\item {} 
Not found

\item {} 
Ambiguous (due to multiple advisors having the same name)

\end{enumerate}

\end{description}

\end{enumerate}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{path}} \textendash{} A string; Represents a full file path.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{alter\_name}} \textendash{} A string; Represents a suffix to append to a full file path.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{scrape\_type}} \textendash{} A string; The scrape type (‘all’, see self.\_x\_paths above, or ‘crdnumber’) they desire to perform.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parse\_list}} \textendash{} Boolean; Used to enable the list parsing (see 3) above).

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{save}} \textendash{} Boolean; Determines whether scraped results are saved to a file path or returned to the user in a console.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Dependent on save parameter above.}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Scraped results are saved to a file path or returned to the user in a console.}

\end{itemize}


\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

\index{split\_list() (in module ListManagement.utility.sf\_helper)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index:ListManagement.utility.sf_helper.split_list}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ListManagement.utility.sf\_helper.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{split\_list}}}{\emph{id\_in\_obj}, \emph{ids\_from\_search}, \emph{obj\_id}, \emph{obj}, \emph{col=None}, \emph{remove=None}, \emph{remove\_unique=None}}{}
Helper function to take two lists and parse them into 2 to 3 different lists.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi )}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi )}\makeatother
\item {} 
If any ‘ids\_from\_search’ aren’t present in ‘id\_in\_obj’, add to insert.

\item {} 
If any ‘ids\_from\_search’ are present in ‘id\_in\_obj’, add to update.

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{If any ‘id\_in\_obj’ aren’t present in ‘ids\_from\_search’, add to remove.}] \leavevmode
(Only happens for BizDev Group Lists)

\end{description}

\end{enumerate}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{id\_in\_obj}} \textendash{} A list of unique identifiers present in a Salesforce object.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ids\_from\_search}} \textendash{} A list of unique identifiers present in a 3rd party list.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{obj\_id}} \textendash{} An 18-char string; Represents an Id of a Salesforce object.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{obj}} \textendash{} A string; Represents the name of a Salesforce object.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{col\_num}} \textendash{} An integer; The column to use for when parsing a list.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{remove}} \textendash{} An empty list.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{remove\_unique}} \textendash{} REMOVE AS NOT USED.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode


\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
A tuple of lists (insert, update, remove)

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}
